awd_titl_txt: MRI: Development of a 100 kHz, Ultrafast Interfacial-Specific Two-Dimensional Vibrational Spectromicroscope
awd_abstract_narration:
This award is supported by the Major Research Instrumentation (MRI) and the Chemistry Research Instrumentation (CRIF) Programs.  Professor Wei Xiong from University of California San Diego and colleagues Vicki Grassian, Neal Devaraj and Ping Liu have developed an ultrafast, one-dimensional/two-dimensional sum frequency generation (1D/2D SFG) spectromicroscope.  The microscope employs a laser to probe a sample. This produces a signal (or image) observed by the microscope. The spectral image provides information on the physical and chemical properties of the sample.  It is used to probe interfaces, for example, the surface of aerosol particles. Another use is to study the structure of water in confined spaces such as in water purification materials.  It is used to pinpoint domains where ice nucleation occurs. Development of artificial retinas and wearable solar cells are applications which can benefit from this instrument. Investigation of these and other processes leads to a better understanding of how to improve them or ameliorate undue consequences. Graduate students are involved with development and application of the instrument, receiving training in an important skill sought by commercial instrument firms. 

The instrument is used in a variety of investigations.  Water purification materials are being studied.  The electrochemical interface of energy storage devices (for example, lithium batteries) is being explored. Aerosols surfaces are receiving attention to understand formation mechanisms.  Materials which have heterogeneous surfaces are better understood using the microscope, for example biological fibrils.  It is being used to study artificial cells and neural networks.  Investigators at the University of California, Irvine and Spelman College have projects using the instrument.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
We developed two VSFG microscope. The microscope has now been deployed to study biological tissues that are related to pathology questions. 

1.  We developed the first transient VSFG microscope and applied it to study H-bond dynamics of self-assembled materials. Using this new technique, we found that the H-bond dynamics are spatially heterogeneous between domains and homogeneous within each domain. Furthermore, we found the H-bond dynamics is Forster resonant energy transfer. Based on this mechanism, we determined the local hydration level of each self-assembled sheet. this result is published in PNAS.

2. We successfully developed a fast linescaning VSFG microscopy. We were able to resolve the microscopic structure at a resolution of less than 2 µm on a target sample (gold pattern with known dimension deposited on quartz). Our VSFG technique can well resolve the morphology microstructures of self-assemblies and provide vibrational spectra to help decode their molecular information. This result is published in JPCB. 

3. Using the fast linescannign VSFG microscope, we sought to study the self-assembled sheets of beta-cyclodextrin (BCD) as a model system using our VSFG microscopy for their strong SFG signal. To simplify the system, we prepared the BCD single sheet to reduce the stacking of randomly oriented sheets by utilizing the spin-coating technique and fine adjusting the coating parameters. Figure 1 is the spectral map of BCD sample under PPS polarization condition. Spectral map is the processed result after spectral unmixing and matching analysis on the hyperspectral image. It shows the spectral similarity between each pixel and it can be clearly visualized that each BCD sheet can be recognized and differentiated from each other.  Moreover, by overlaying the spectral map with the optical image, we can see the sheet structure is well resolved on under our VSFG microscopy.This result is published in JPCB along with 2. 

4. We used this experimental setup to study water absorption mechanism in MOFs. SFG can specifically probe water adsorbed at the interior surfaces of MOFs. Through spectral line shape comparison between VSFG and IR spectra, the relative humidity dependence of VSFG intensity, and MD simulations, based on MB-pol, we found water clustering and center pore filling happen nearly simultaneously within each pore, with water filling the other pores sequentially.This molecular-level detailed mechanism can inform the rational optimization of metal−organic frameworks for water harvesting.

5. A review paper on these activities has been published in the Annual Review of Physical Chemistry

6. another review paper has been published in Langmuir

Two students have earned their PhD degrees, and I have hosted URM undergraduate researchers from HBCU during the course of this project.

Modified by: Wei Xiong
